articles.headline: After Bird Flu Scare, Plenty of Turkeys for Thanksgiving
articles.snippet: When 7.5 million turkeys had to be killed because of avian flu, prices for the Thanksgiving birds were expected to soar. In fact, they are among the lowest in years.
articles.abstract: When 7.5 million turkeys had to be killed because of avian flu, prices for the Thanksgiving birds were expected to soar. In fact, they are among the lowest in years.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the doomsaying turkey pundits had been right, we’d all be eating ham this Thanksgiving.

articles.headline: UnitedHealth Lowers Forecast, Blaming Affordable Care Act
articles.snippet: Citing weak growth in the numbers of new people signing up for coverage, the company said it was reducing its earnings estimates for 2015 and 2016.
articles.abstract: Citing weak growth in the numbers of new people signing up for coverage, the company said it was reducing its earnings estimates for 2015 and 2016.
articles.lead_paragraph: UnitedHealth Group, one of the nation’s largest health insurance companies, stunned investors on Thursday morning when it significantly lowered its profit estimates, placing the blame for an expected loss of hundreds of millions of dollars on selling individual policies under the federal health care law.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Goes Beyond President Obama in Plan to Defeat ISIS
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton called for speeding up the American-led operations against the Islamic State including a no-fly zone and more airstrikes.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton called for speeding up the American-led operations against the Islamic State including a no-fly zone and more airstrikes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton called on Thursday for accelerating the American-led operation to defeat the Islamic State, going well beyond what President Obama has proposed by urging a no-fly zone with coalition forces to protect Syrians, more airstrikes and an expanded deployment of special operations troops to assist local ground forces.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: House Approves Tougher Refugee Screening, Defying Veto Threat
articles.snippet: Lawmakers voted overwhelmingly to impose stringent new screening procedures on people from Syria and Iraq seeking resettlement in the United States.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers voted overwhelmingly to impose stringent new screening procedures on people from Syria and Iraq seeking resettlement in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House voted overwhelmingly Thursday to drastically tighten screening procedures on refugees from Syria, seizing on the creeping fear stemming from the Paris attacks and threatening to undermine President Obama’s Middle East policy.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Economic Fallout of Paris Attacks Hits Hotels Hard
articles.snippet: Executives in the hospitality industry are taking stock of the potential losses as cancellations surge.
articles.abstract: Executives in the hospitality industry are taking stock of the potential losses as cancellations surge.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The first wave of canceled reservations struck Le Bristol with crushing force after last weekend’s terrorist attacks, across town from the five-star hotel and its elite Right Bank neighborhood. Within 72 hours, the tally of lost bookings exceeded a half-million euros — more than $530,000.

articles.headline: Buffett’s Grandson Seeks Own Investment Route: Social Change
articles.snippet: Hoping to build on his family’s legacy, Howard Warren Buffett has co-founded i(x) Investments to put capital to work in ways he hopes will improve the world.
articles.abstract: Hoping to build on his family’s legacy, Howard Warren Buffett has co-founded i(x) Investments to put capital to work in ways he hopes will improve the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 32, Howard Warren Buffett, the grandson of the Berkshire Hathaway founder Warren E. Buffett, has already enjoyed a diverse career.

articles.headline: Google Picks Diane Greene to Expand Its Cloud Business
articles.snippet: Ms. Greene, a Silicon Valley veteran, has been a board member of Google and founded Bebop Technologies, which Google has agreed to buy.
articles.abstract: Ms. Greene, a Silicon Valley veteran, has been a board member of Google and founded Bebop Technologies, which Google has agreed to buy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google is playing catch-up in the booming cloud computing market, well behind the early leader, Amazon. But on Thursday, Google made clear that it was ready to go on the offensive.

articles.headline: As France and Belgium Strengthen Security, a Classic Debate Arises
articles.snippet: The two nations are each acting to toughen emergency powers in the wake of the Paris attacks, but some wonder if the cost to personal liberty is too great.
articles.abstract: The two nations are each acting to toughen emergency powers in the wake of the Paris attacks, but some wonder if the cost to personal liberty is too great.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Shocked by the carnage of the Paris attacks, France and Belgium moved aggressively on Thursday to strengthen the hand of their security forces, pushing Europe more deeply into a debate that has raged in the United States since Sept. 11, 2001: how to balance counterterrorism efforts and civil liberties.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura

articles.headline: As Investors Shun Debt, Banks Are Left Holding the Bag
articles.snippet: As investors have suddenly become more risk-averse, big Wall Street banks have been stuck with piles of debt that they are struggling to sell.
articles.abstract: As investors have suddenly become more risk-averse, big Wall Street banks have been stuck with piles of debt that they are struggling to sell.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent years, Wall Street firms have reaped big profits in the scrappy reaches of the credit markets, selling the debt of companies with weak credit ratings to investors who crave higher returns.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Leslie Picker

articles.headline: Deadly Siege Ends After Assault on Hotel in Mali
articles.snippet: Gunmen stormed a Radisson Blu hotel on Friday morning in Bamako, seizing scores of hostages and leaving bodies strewn across parts of the building.
articles.abstract: Gunmen stormed a Radisson Blu hotel on Friday morning in Bamako, seizing scores of hostages and leaving bodies strewn across parts of the building.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Heavily armed gunmen shouting “Allahu akbar” stormed a Radisson Blu Hotel early Friday in Bamako, the capital of the West African nation of Mali, seizing scores of hostages and leaving bodies strewed across the building.
articles.byline: By Dionne Searcey and Adam Nossiter

articles.headline: VW Cuts Its R.&D. Budget in Face of Costly Emissions Scandal
articles.snippet: The trim — more than $1 billion from last year’s budget — is the first time since the financial crisis that Volkswagen has not increased investment.
articles.abstract: The trim — more than $1 billion from last year’s budget — is the first time since the financial crisis that Volkswagen has not increased investment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOLFSBURG, Germany — Scarred by an emissions-cheating scandal, Volkswagen on Friday said it would need to cut its budget next year for new technology and research — a reversal after years of increased spending aimed at becoming the world’s biggest carmaker.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: LivingSocial Offers a Cautionary Tale to Today’s Unicorns
articles.snippet: A former darling of the start-up world, the company offers a glimpse of what some of today’s biggest start-ups might look like several years down the road.
articles.abstract: A former darling of the start-up world, the company offers a glimpse of what some of today’s biggest start-ups might look like several years down the road.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The first thing you see when walking into the headquarters of LivingSocial is row upon row of mostly empty desks, broken up by small street signs that employees once needed to find one another when the office teemed with people.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Katie Benner

articles.headline: WWII Hero Credits Luck and Chance in Foiling Hitler’s Nuclear Ambitions
articles.snippet: Joachim Ronneberg of Norway says that just before his sabotage mission, he happened upon a tool that was crucial in destroying the Nazis’ supply of a fluid used to create nuclear weapons.
articles.abstract: Joachim Ronneberg of Norway says that just before his sabotage mission, he happened upon a tool that was crucial in destroying the Nazis’ supply of a fluid used to create nuclear weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALESUND, Norway — For a man who saved the world, or at least helped ensure that Adolf Hitler never got hold of a nuclear bomb, 96-year-old Joachim Ronneberg has a surprisingly unheroic view of the forces that shape history.

articles.headline: In Defense of the Personal Crowdfunding Campaign
articles.snippet: More people who are in bad, but not dire, financial situations are turning to sites like GoFundMe for help covering costs including medical care and tuition.
articles.abstract: More people who are in bad, but not dire, financial situations are turning to sites like GoFundMe for help covering costs including medical care and tuition.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I can’t even believe I’m writing this, or asking for this, but this is the reality.”
